user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_register_generic_device:
```c
int metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	if (!device->name || !strlen(device->name) ||
	    device->num_regions > METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS)
		return -EINVAL;

	device->bus = &metal_generic_bus;
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_device_list,
			    &device->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_register_generic_device:
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct metal_bus metal_weak metal_generic_bus = {
	.name = "generic",
	.ops  = {
		.bus_close = NULL,
		.dev_open  = metal_generic_dev_open,
		.dev_close = NULL,
		.dev_irq_ack = NULL,
		.dev_dma_map = metal_generic_dev_dma_map,
		.dev_dma_unmap = metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap,
	},
}
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
explanation: Other pointer-containing fragments in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: the device->name member is already const-qualified (const char *name), so it satisfies the rule; the function parameter metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device) cannot be const because the function writes to the device (assigns device->bus and links device->node), so const-qualification is not possible there; the regions array and node member are not pointer-typed (they are an array and a struct, respectively) and thus Rule 8.13 does not apply; the initializer entries under .ops are function pointers/NULL initializers (function pointers are a different category and the rule targets pointers to object data), so they are not candidates for const-qualification in this context; other declarations shown (extern struct metal_state _metal) are not pointer-to-object types relevant to this rule. Therefore only the listed fragments warrant further investigation for possible const qualification.
